one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle‑aged woman with HIV/AIDS (CD4 6), ESRD on hemodialysis, and prior herpes zoster ophthalmicus with post‑herpetic neuralgia presented from dialysis with worsening right‑sided headache and facial pain, blurry vision, diffuse pruritic rash, dizziness, and hypotension. Initial ED vitals showed systolic BP in the 70s–80s and leukopenia; she received about 3 L of IV fluids, broad‑spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin, cefepime) and acyclovir for possible line or CNS infection or zoster reactivation, and was admitted to the MICU. CT head showed no acute intracranial process but marked falx/tentorium calcifications attributed to ESRD, and chest X‑ray showed clear lungs and a well‑positioned inferior dialysis catheter without acute disease. Labs demonstrated chronic macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, ESRD‑range creatinine and BUN, mild hyperphosphatemia, and very low CD4 count. She had a brief episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response during fluid resuscitation, then reverted to sinus rhythm; troponin was mildly elevated with normal CK/CK‑MB. With stabilization of blood pressure near her low baseline and no clear infectious source, antibiotics and acyclovir were discontinued, and a cosyntropin stimulation test ruled out adrenal insufficiency. Dermatologic findings were consistent with eosinophilic folliculitis and chronic post‑herpetic changes; pruritus was treated with fexofenadine and Sarna lotion, and post‑herpetic neuralgia with amitriptyline plus PRN oxycodone and acetaminophen. Ophthalmology found no new ocular zoster. She continued cinacalcet, sevelamer, and thrice‑weekly hemodialysis, with transient intradialytic hypotension responding to a small saline bolus. HIV prophylaxis with TMP‑SMX three times weekly and azithromycin weekly was restarted. By discharge she was hemodynamically stable at her baseline, ambulatory, with improved pain and pruritus, and was discharged home on her chronic dialysis schedule and updated medications, with outpatient follow‑up arranged.

problem_list.problem: Hypotension and dizziness in the setting of ESRD and HIV
problem_list.status_at_discharge: On presentation she was hypotensive (systolic BP in the 70s–80s) with dizziness and leukopenia, meeting SIRS criteria. She received approximately 3 L of normal saline with improvement of systolic BP into the 90s–100s. Broad‑spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin, cefepime) and acyclovir were started empirically for possible line or CNS infection or zoster reactivation. CT head and CXR showed no acute process, lactate was only mildly elevated, and no clear infectious source was identified. Cosyntropin stimulation testing showed an adequate cortisol response, ruling out adrenal insufficiency. Her blood pressure stabilized near her chronic low baseline (80s–90s systolic), and antibiotics and acyclovir were discontinued. She had transient intradialytic hypotension on the floor that responded to a 200 cc NS bolus. At discharge she was asymptomatic with baseline low BP and no evidence of sepsis or adrenal failure.

problem_list.problem: Herpes zoster ophthalmicus with post‑herpetic neuralgia and headache
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She had a history of herpes zoster involving the right eye and scalp with chronic post‑herpetic neuralgia. She presented with acute worsening right‑sided headache and facial pain after self‑increasing gabapentin and then stopping it. Exam showed erythematous plaques and erosions over the right face and forehead and chronic right eye changes; fluorescein exam in the ED and Ophthalmology consultation did not reveal new corneal lesions or acute ocular zoster. She was initially covered with IV acyclovir, which was stopped once no acute reactivation was evident. For neuralgia, amitriptyline 25 mg at bedtime was restarted, along with PRN oxycodone and acetaminophen. By discharge, her headache and facial pain had improved, and she was sent home on amitriptyline and PRN analgesics.

problem_list.problem: Eosinophilic folliculitis and diffuse pruritic rash
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She had a chronic, intensely pruritic rash with hyperpigmented follicular papules over the extensor surfaces of the extremities, chest, and abdomen, with excoriations and relative sparing of the back. In the context of advanced HIV, this was clinically felt to be eosinophilic folliculitis rather than disseminated zoster. She had peripheral eosinophilia on admission. Pruritus was managed with fexofenadine (initially 180 mg daily, then 60 mg BID) and topical Sarna lotion. By discharge, her itching was improved, and she was discharged on fexofenadine 60 mg BID with instructions to continue topical therapy.

She has ESRD from HIV nephropathy and is anuric on chronic hemodialysis. During this admission she continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis via an inferior approach dialysis catheter seen on CXR. Pre‑dialysis labs showed creatinine up to 9.8 mg/dL, BUN 57 mg/dL, and potassium 5.3 mEq/L, with post‑dialysis values improving (creatinine ~7 mg/dL, BUN 34 mg/dL, potassium 4.9 mEq/L). She experienced transient intradialytic hypotension that responded to a 200 cc NS bolus. She remained on cinacalcet and sevelamer for secondary hyperparathyroidism and phosphate control, and received doxercalciferol with dialysis. At discharge she was stable, with plans to continue her prior outpatient dialysis schedule and ESRD medications.

problem_list.problem: Atrial fibrillation and cardiac rhythm abnormalities
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has a history of atrial fibrillation. During this admission she developed atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (HR ~117) during fluid resuscitation in the ED, associated with a transient "funny" chest sensation. Repeat ECG on the floor showed sinus rhythm. Troponin T was mildly elevated (0.24–0.26 ng/mL) with normal CK and CK‑MB, interpreted as a non‑ischemic elevation in the setting of ESRD and hypotension. She remained hemodynamically stable without chest pain. Given a low stroke risk and concerns about adherence and bleeding, she was managed with aspirin 325 mg daily without systemic anticoagulation. At discharge she was in sinus rhythm and clinically stable.

problem_list.problem: HIV/AIDS with severe immunosuppression and opportunistic infection prophylaxis
problem_list.status_at_discharge: She has advanced HIV/AIDS with a CD4 count of 6 cells/µL and a history of multiple opportunistic infections including PCP and zoster. She was off HAART at admission due to prior non‑adherence and intolerance, and antiretroviral therapy was not restarted in hospital. Her CD4 and CD8 subsets confirmed profound immunosuppression with a CD4/CD8 ratio of 0.0. She had stopped TMP‑SMX and azithromycin prophylaxis prior to admission; these were restarted in hospital as TMP‑SMX DS one tablet three times weekly and azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. She was discharged still off HAART but with prescriptions for TMP‑SMX and azithromycin and instructions to follow up with her HIV provider.

Throughout the admission she had leukopenia (WBC 2.1–2.8 K/uL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 101–119 K/uL), and macrocytosis (MCV 102–104 fL) with hemoglobin ranging from 11.1–12.6 g/dL. Coagulation studies (PT, INR, PTT) were within normal limits. No bleeding events or transfusions were documented. The cytopenias were attributed to HIV‑related bone marrow suppression and chronic disease. At discharge her counts remained stable and she was clinically well.

key_tests_and_results.result: Noncontrast CT of the head showed no acute hemorrhage, edema, large territorial infarction, mass effect, or midline shift. There were exuberant calcifications of the falx and tentorium cerebelli and calcifications in the left basal ganglia, likely related to underlying end‑stage renal disease. No acute intracranial process was identified.

Frontal and lateral chest radiographs demonstrated well‑expanded, clear lungs without focal consolidation, effusion, pneumothorax, or pulmonary edema. Heart size, mediastinal silhouette, and hilar contours were normal. An inferior approach dialysis catheter was seen with its tip in the right atrium. No acute intrathoracic process was identified.

key_tests_and_results.test: Initial laboratory evaluation (CBC, BMP, cardiac enzymes, CD4 count)
key_tests_and_results.result: Admission labs showed leukopenia (WBC 2.4–2.5 K/uL), macrocytosis (MCV ~103 fL), platelets ~101 K/uL, hemoglobin 12.6 g/dL, creatinine 5.8–7.0 mg/dL, BUN 27–34 mg/dL, potassium 4.4–4.9 mEq/L, bicarbonate 20–24 mEq/L, and mild hyperphosphatemia (phosphate 4.9 mg/dL). Troponin T was mildly elevated at 0.24–0.26 ng/mL with normal CK and CK‑MB. CD4 count was 6 cells/µL with CD4% 1%, CD8% 84%, and CD4/CD8 ratio 0.0, indicating profound immunosuppression.

Baseline and stimulated cortisol levels after IV cosyntropin administration showed an appropriate rise, with values in the low‑normal to elevated range, ruling out adrenal insufficiency as a cause of hypotension.

key_tests_and_results.test: Serial chemistry and hematology during hospitalization
key_tests_and_results.result: Over the course of admission, serial labs demonstrated stable macrocytic anemia (hemoglobin 11.1–11.6 g/dL, MCV 102–104 fL), persistent leukopenia (WBC 2.1–2.8 K/uL), and thrombocytopenia (platelets 101–119 K/uL). Renal indices fluctuated with dialysis, with pre‑dialysis creatinine up to 9.8 mg/dL and BUN 57 mg/dL, improving post‑dialysis to creatinine ~7.0 mg/dL and BUN 34 mg/dL; potassium was controlled between 4.9 and 5.3 mEq/L.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Initial resuscitation and empiric antimicrobial therapy
treatments_and_meds.details: In the ED she presented with hypotension and dizziness after dialysis and met SIRS criteria with leukopenia. She received approximately 3 L of IV normal saline, which improved her systolic blood pressure from the 70s to the 90s–100s. Empiric broad‑spectrum antimicrobials were started, including IV vancomycin and cefepime for possible line or CNS infection and IV acyclovir for possible herpes zoster reactivation. Once her blood pressure stabilized near baseline and no clear infectious source was identified, cefepime, vancomycin, and acyclovir were discontinued.

She continued thrice‑weekly hemodialysis during the admission. Pre‑dialysis labs showed elevated creatinine (up to 9.8 mg/dL), BUN 57 mg/dL, and potassium 5.3 mEq/L, which improved post‑dialysis (creatinine ~7.0 mg/dL, BUN 34 mg/dL, potassium 4.9 mEq/L). She experienced intradialytic hypotension with systolic BP in the 60s–70s that responded to a 200 cc NS bolus. Chronic ESRD medications, including cinacalcet 60 mg daily and sevelamer carbonate 3200 mg TID with meals, were continued. She also received IV doxercalciferol and heparin during dialysis sessions.

Given her CD4 count of 6 cells/µL and history of opportunistic infections, she was restarted on Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with sulfamethoxazole‑trimethoprim DS one tablet three times per week and Mycobacterium avium complex prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. These were initiated during hospitalization and prescribed at discharge, while full antiretroviral therapy was deferred to outpatient management.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Evaluation and management of adrenal function
treatments_and_meds.details: Because of hypotension and eosinophilia, adrenal insufficiency was considered. Baseline cortisol levels were in the low‑normal range, and a cosyntropin stimulation test was performed using IV cosyntropin 250 mcg. Serial cortisol measurements demonstrated an adequate rise, ruling out adrenal insufficiency. No chronic steroid therapy was initiated.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Management of post‑herpetic neuralgia and pain control
treatments_and_meds.details: Her chronic right facial and scalp pain from post‑herpetic neuralgia was managed by restarting amitriptyline 25 mg at bedtime, which she had previously tolerated and found effective. Additional analgesia included PRN oxycodone immediate‑release 5–10 mg PO and acetaminophen 650 mg PO. These measures led to improvement in her headache and facial pain by discharge, and she was sent home with prescriptions for amitriptyline and PRN analgesics.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Treatment of eosinophilic folliculitis and pruritus
treatments_and_meds.details: Her diffuse pruritic rash, clinically consistent with eosinophilic folliculitis in the setting of HIV, was treated symptomatically. She received fexofenadine, initially 180 mg daily then adjusted to 60 mg twice daily, and topical Sarna lotion as needed. These therapies reduced her itching, and she was discharged on fexofenadine 60 mg BID with instructions to continue topical emollients.

In light of her history of atrial fibrillation and a new episode during fluid resuscitation, her stroke risk and bleeding risk were reassessed. Given a low CHADS2 score and concerns about adherence and bleeding, systemic anticoagulation was not started. She was maintained on aspirin 325 mg daily for stroke prophylaxis.
